thread.title: 2 arrests made in weekend shootings
thread.title_full: 2 arrests made in weekend shootings | savannahnow.com

author: Savannah Morning News
title: 2 arrests made in weekend shootings
text:
Photos Back | Next Back | Next SPECIAL OFFER FOR NEW READERS 99 cent digital subscription to savannahnow.com

SIGN UP FOR SUBSCRIBER BENEFITS As a Savannah Morning News / savannahnow.com subscriber, you're eligible for members-only discounts. Download your coupons now. By Savannah Morning News Two arrests were made in a pair of weekend shootings.
In the first shooting, Savannah-Chatham police Violent Crimes detectives on Sunday morning arrested and charged Daquan Bryant, 17, in a Saturday night shooting on the 500 block of Yamacraw Village. That shooting injured a 20-year-old California man, according to police spokeswoman Eunicia Baker.
The shooting was reported just after 11 p.m.
Metro officers responded to the scene and found the victim suffering from a non-life-threatening gunshot wound, Baker said. The man was transported by ambulance to Memorial University Medical Center for care.
The victim and an 18-year-old friend were together on River Street where they encountered a group of individuals. The two reportedly accepted an invitation by the group to accompany them to Yamacraw Village. Once they arrived at the 500 block of Yamacraw Village, a male suspect produced a gun and demanded the pair’s belongings, Baker said. The men ran away. The 20-year-old was shot while attempting to flee.
Nearby metro officers noticed several males, including Bryant, running west over the Bay Street viaduct. Officers stopped
and detained the men for identification. They were transported to police headquarters for interviews, Baker said. Investigators determined that Bryant was the shooter. Bryant was charged with two counts of aggravated assault and two counts of armed robbery. He was transported to the Chatham County jail.
Two persons of interest also are sought for questioning in this investigation. Both are black males, possibly in their teens, Baker said. The first is described as tall, with a light complexion. During the incident he wore a red hooded sweatshirt. The second subject is described as short with a dark skin tone, possibly wearing a blue and red striped shirt during the incident.
In the second weekend shooting, Savannah-Chatham police Violent Crimes detectives arrested and charged Darius Javon Black, 23, in the attempted robbery of three men that resulted in a shooting on Abercorn and East Bryan streets at about 3:12 a.m. Sunday.
Police responded to the scene, where two men, a 21-year-old and a 22-year-old, were subduing a male subject, later identified as Black, said police spokeswoman Eunicia Baker. A second suspect fled the area. Black attempted to run when a Downtown Precinct patrol officer followed him. Black and the officer made contact nearby, Baker said. They engaged in a brief scuffle before Black was detained by the officer. The officer sustained minor injuries, Baker said.
Additional metro units at Abercorn and East Bryan streets located a 23-year-old man suffering from a non-life-threatening gunshot wound. The victim was transported by ambulance to Memorial University Medical Center for treatment, Baker said.
Investigators learned that all three men were robbed by Black and another male suspect after leaving a nearby club. The second suspect reportedly displayed a gun as both suspects demanded the group’s belongings. The group refused, resulting in a fight between themselves and the suspects, Baker said. During the fight, Black allegedly obtained the gun and fired, hitting the 23-year-old. The 21-year-old also was transported to Memorial with non-life-threatening injuries from the fight, Baker said.
Black was arrested and charged with two counts of aggravated assault, felony obstruction and obstruction by fleeing.
Investigators now seek a second suspect described as a heavy-set black male.
Anyone with information on either of these cases should call CrimeStoppers at 912-234-2020 or text CRIMES (274637) using the keyword CSTOP2020. Tipsters remain anonymous and may qualify for a cash reward.
A confidential tip line also is open directly to investigators at 912-525-3124.
Construction begins this week on I-95 at U.S. 17
Georgia Department of Transportation will begin reconstruction of the Interstate 95 bridge over U.S. 17/Ga. 25 this week. Contractors for Georgia DOT have scheduled lane closures and traffic shifts at I-95 and U.S. 17/Ga. 25 in Richmond Hill, said Jill Nagel, GDOT spokeswoman. Lane closures and traffic shifts will be utilized for staging and construction work to replace the damaged bridge beam.
“In an effort to minimize the impact to the traveling public and the duration of the project, construction work will be continuous until the repairs are completed, weather permitting. US 17/SR 25 and I-95 southbound will have reduced speed limits in the construction zone. We ask the public to be patient during this time and find alternate routes in lieu of U.S. 17 at I-95 overpass,” Nagel said.
Closures will include:
• Today: I-95 Southbound double lane closure from 7 p.m. to 7 a.m.
• Tuesday: U.S. 17/Ga. 25 traffic shifts starts at 7 p.m.
• Wednesday: I-95 southbound single right lane closure from 7 p.m. until 7 a.m.
• Thursday: I-95 southbound double lane closure from 7 p.m. to 7 a.m.
• Friday: I-95 southbound traffic shift with double right lane closures starts at 7 p.m.
Savannah-Chatham police investigate Bay Street cutting
Savannah-Chatham police Violent Crimes detectives obtained an aggravated assault warrant on Saturday for the arrest of Anthony Fleming, 56, sought for a cutting that injured a man on the 1300 block of West Bay Street last Friday.
Friday, at about 6:19 p.m., metro responded to the scene to find Anthony Mouzon, 56, with lacerations sustained during a fight with a male suspect believed to be Fleming. Mouzon was transported by ambulance to Memorial University Medical Center with non-life-threatening injuries, according to police spokeswoman Eunicia Baker.
Fleming is described as a black male, possibly wearing a white and black hat and blue shirt during the incident. The suspect may have fled on a blue bicycle, Baker said.
Investigators believe the victim and suspect are acquainted and may have had a dispute over money, Baker said.
Anyone with information on this case should call CrimeStoppers at 912-234-2020 or text CRIMES (274637) using the keyword CSTOP2020. Tipsters remain anonymous and may qualify for a cash reward.
A confidential tip line also is open directly to investigators at 912-525-3124.
Savannah-Chatham police investigate Thursday night shootings
Savannah-Chatham police Department’s Violent Crimes detectives are investigating two shootings that occurred on Thursday night.
At about 8:17 p.m. metro responded to a residence in the 2100 block of South Fernwood Drive, where a 20-year-old was suffering from a gunshot wound. The victim was transported to Memorial University Medical Center with non-life-threatening injuries, said police spokeswoman Eunicia Baker.
He was reportedly outside of the residence talking on the phone when shots were fired from a dark colored car, Baker said.
At roughly 8:41 p.m. metro responded to a shots fired call at Pendleton Street and Liberty Parkway. Minutes later, police learned that a 36-year-old gunshot victim had driven himself to Candler Hospital in a privately owned vehicle for treatment of non-life-threatening injuries.
Smart was reportedly entering his vehicle on the 2100 Block of Pendleton Street, when a male approached the victim on foot and opened fire as he drove off.
The suspect is described as a black male, possibly in his 20s, with a light complexion.
Circumstances surrounding these shootings remain under investigation. Detectives do not believe these cases are connected.
Anyone with information on this case should call CrimeStoppers at 912-234-2020 or text CRIMES (274637) using the keyword CSTOP2020. Tipsters remain anonymous and may qualify for a cash reward.
